content.text: Cambridge examinations are a core measure of academic credibility for Eduversal Partner Schools. This section defines the systems required to maintain integrity, security, fairness, and full compliance across all examination series.

content.title: Primary Objectives
items: Protect assessment integrity through secure and standardized procedures.
Ensure candidates have fair access and consistent examination conditions.
Maintain full compliance with Cambridge Centre regulations and timelines.
Use examination outcomes for quality assurance and school improvement.

content.text: Strong governance prevents operational gaps and ensures clear accountability from board level to exam room implementation.

content.title: Principal (Head of Centre)
resp: Holds ultimate accountability for Cambridge examination compliance.
Approves entries, key decisions, and annual declaration submissions.
Leads formal response for serious incidents and malpractice.

content.title: Exams Officer
resp: Manages the end-to-end examination cycle: entries, timetables, rooms, dispatch, and records.
Maintains secure materials logs and key-time compliance controls.
Coordinates post-results services, certificate handling, and reporting.

content.title: Quality Nominee and Academic Leaders
resp: Monitor quality of assessment implementation and policy alignment.
Review results data and drive post-series improvement actions.
Ensure training completion and procedural consistency across departments.

content.title: Invigilators and Support Staff
resp: Run examinations exactly to approved scripts and instructions.
Maintain supervision, candidate identity checks, and incident reporting.
Protect exam-room integrity from opening to script collection.

content.text: The Board receives an annual examinations report covering outcomes, compliance status, incidents, and budget performance.

content.title: Minimum Annual Report Content
items: Participation rates, pass rates, grade trends, and benchmark movement.
Cambridge compliance and inspection/notification summary.
Malpractice and maladministration incident review.
Budget versus actual expenditure and improvement recommendations.

content.text: Examination materials must be protected against unauthorized access, tampering, loss, or environmental damage from receipt to dispatch.

content.title: Physical Security Controls
items: Dedicated secure room/cabinet with robust construction and dual-lock controls.
Restricted key access and documented entry logs.
Appropriate environmental controls (temperature, humidity, and fire risk mitigation).
No unauthorized personnel access at any time.

content.title: Minimum Secure Storage Evidence
rows: Named key holders and signed access log
Incident-free audits or corrective action records

content.text: Cambridge key times are mandatory. Material handling must follow chain-of-custody procedures at every step.

content.title: Materials Receipt Process
items: Verify courier identity and delivery documentation.
Check package integrity and reconcile against packing list.
Log date/time/condition in secure storage register.
Store immediately without premature opening.

content.title: Materials Dispatch Process
items: Pack scripts in approved envelopes/containers.
Complete dispatch manifests and required forms.
Use tracked courier service with signature confirmation.
Retain proof-of-dispatch documentation for audits.

content.text: Standardized exam-day protocols ensure fairness, security, and consistency across all rooms and sessions.

items: Confirm room bookings, signage, and seating plans.
Set desk spacing to Cambridge requirements and verify visible synchronized clocks.
Prepare candidate instruction notices and invigilator packs.
For e-assessments, test devices, software, network controls, and backup capacity.

content.title: Opening Protocol (Before Start)
items: Invigilators collect materials and verify session documentation.
Admit candidates and verify identity against seating plan.
Remove prohibited items and apply approved storage controls.
Read standard candidate instructions and start exam on synchronized time.

content.title: Core Invigilation Controls
items: Continuous room supervision and movement checks.
Accurate attendance and late-arrival handling.
Prompt incident documentation and escalation.
Secure script collection and count reconciliation at close.

content.text: Candidates with timetable clashes follow approved clash-management pathways under strict supervision to preserve integrity.

items: Different start times with supervised secure rest break.
Alternative supervised sequence where permitted by Cambridge regulations.
No candidate contact or information-sharing during clash control periods.
Documented principal approval and full invigilation records.

content.text: All incidents are managed through a predefined response protocol to protect candidate welfare and examination validity.

items: Secure immediate safety and exam integrity.
Record facts and collect evidence within 24 hours.
Notify leadership and Cambridge where required.
Implement follow-up actions and candidate support.

content.text: Schools must distinguish candidate malpractice from centre maladministration and manage both through transparent, evidence-based processes.

rows: Candidate behavior that creates unfair advantage or compromises integrity
Centre/staff process failure affecting fairness or security
Procedure breach, timing error, insecure handling

items: Initial incident report and evidence collection (0-24 hours).
Preliminary review by Principal and Exams Officer (1-3 days).
Candidate/parent meeting and recorded response (3-5 days).
Decision, sanctions (if any), and Cambridge report submission (5-7 days).
Case closure record with appeals route communication.

content.text: Procedures ensure equitable candidate access without compromising standards or examination validity.

items: Pre-approved adjustments for documented needs (e.g., extra time, reader, scribe, separate room).
Applications supported by professional evidence and submitted by deadline.
Arrangements practiced in normal classroom assessment to demonstrate usual way of working.
Implementation logs maintained for each affected exam.
Post-exam adjustment requests for temporary adverse circumstances.
Evidence may include medical notes, incident records, or bereavement documentation.
Applications must meet Cambridge criteria and submission timelines.
Candidate and family are informed of scope and limitations of outcomes.

content.text: Post-series processes include results analysis, service requests, certificate controls, and records assurance.

items: Download and verify official results data.
Analyze pass rates, grade distributions, and component-level performance.
Compare outcomes with predictions, prior cohorts, and benchmarks.
Present findings to leadership, board, and academic teams.
Define intervention actions for resits and curriculum improvement.

content.title: Common Post-Results Services
rows: Support teaching feedback and candidate review

content.text: All requests require candidate consent and documented acknowledgement of fee and outcome conditions.

items: Register receipt of certificates and verify against candidate list.
Distribute through controlled collection process with signature records.
Store uncollected certificates securely and track reissue requests.
Maintain archive logs for verification, transcript, and audit needs.

content.text: Examinations require proactive risk planning and continuity arrangements for operational disruptions.

rows: Dual-control storage, access logs, rapid escalation
Courier tracking controls and dispatch deadlines

items: Activate examination continuity plan during major disruption.
Define command structure and communication cascade.
Coordinate with Cambridge on timetable, venue, or access adjustments.
Protect candidate wellbeing and fairness during contingency measures.
Document all continuity decisions for post-series review.

content.text: Examination quality is strengthened through annual review cycles, evidence analysis, and inspection readiness.

items: Conduct post-series review after each major exam series.
Analyze incidents, complaints, results quality, and process delays.
Gather feedback from candidates, invigilators, and subject leaders.
Update procedures, templates, and training plans.
Track implementation of corrective actions before next series.

content.title: Inspection Readiness Essentials
items: Current secure storage logs and invigilator training records.
Access arrangement evidence linked to candidates.
Archived room plans, scripts documentation, and incident files.
Annual declaration records and Cambridge correspondence.
Prompt, transparent evidence sharing during inspection visits.

content.text: Clear communication reduces candidate anxiety, improves preparedness, and supports procedural compliance.

items: Publish exam timelines, entry confirmation windows, and candidate instructions.
Use bilingual communication (English and Bahasa Indonesia) for critical notices.
Provide plain-language guidance on exam rules, prohibited items, and support routes.
Issue results and post-results instructions through controlled official channels.
Share entry lists with subject teams for eligibility verification.
Provide monthly progress and risk updates to senior leadership.
Coordinate predicted grades and post-results analysis workflows.
Communicate incident lessons and procedural updates before each series.

content.text: Examination finance must be transparent, forecast-driven, and aligned with school budgeting and fee policies.

content.title: Fee Responsibility
items: Standard entries may be covered within tuition by school policy.
Late entries, resits, and optional additional subjects are generally parent-funded.
Post-results fees are typically parent-funded and may be refundable if outcome changes.
Prepare budget forecast based on projected entries and subject blocks.
Include contingencies for late entries, invigilation, and logistics.
Submit draft to Principal for integration into annual school budget.
Monitor budget versus actual throughout the year and report variances.
Entry verification checklist and deadline tracker
Secure storage register and chain-of-custody log
Exam-day invigilation script and attendance templates
Incident/malpractice report forms
Post-series review and board reporting templates
Continuity plan and risk assessment templates

content.text: Examination personnel require recurrent professional development to maintain regulatory accuracy and operational quality.

items: Cambridge Exams Officer training within six months of appointment.
At least two annual Cambridge refresher updates/webinars.
Eduversal cross-school practice-sharing sessions.
Professional development logs and certificate evidence in EduNav.

content.title: Standard Annual Invigilator Program
rows: Late arrivals, malpractice, emergencies, tech failure

content.text: Examination operations are integrated with school data, assessment, quality assurance, and communication systems.

content.title: Dashboard Use Cases
items: Exams Officer dashboard: entries, deadlines, secure storage, and budget tracking.
Principal dashboard: results trends, compliance status, and risk indicators.
HoD dashboard: subject-component performance and intervention tracking.
Candidate/parent portal: timetables, results notifications, and service status.
Examination procedures align with Section 6 assessment integrity principles.
Post-results data feeds curriculum and teaching improvement cycles.
Access arrangements and special consideration align with inclusive assessment controls.
Academic integrity expectations are consistent across classroom and external assessment.

categories.title: Cambridge Requirements
items: Centre Handbook compliance for entries, key times, security, malpractice, and post-results services.
Annual declaration accuracy and inspection readiness evidence.
Fair candidate access through approved arrangements and formal records.

categories.title: CIS and WASC
items: Assessment integrity, validity, and reliability standards.
Operational systems quality, risk management, and documented controls.
Student support standards for wellbeing and equitable access.

categories.title: Indonesian Regulatory Context
items: School operational compliance, record handling, and student protection obligations.
Transparent financial and governance reporting for examination operations.
Use post-series report as the evidence baseline.
Incorporate stakeholder feedback from students, parents, and staff.
Integrate updated Cambridge guidance and regulatory changes.
Revise procedures, templates, and training actions.
Approve updates through leadership and board governance cycle.
Publish and communicate updates before next exam series.

content.text: Effective Cambridge examination management reflects institutional rigor. By sustaining secure systems, trained personnel, transparent governance, and continuous review, Eduversal Partner Schools protect candidate trust and uphold international academic standards.
